ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture
N/A
We had recorded lectures once a week and a live virtual lecture once a week.
Pre-recorded lecture on Monday, live lecture on Wednesday
Virtual seminar, recorded lecture, and Perusall discussion application.

In-person seminar 
Asynchronous lectures
Perusal annotations
Recorder lecture once a week

The class was listed as meeting on Mondays and Wednesdays, but the Monday task was asynchronous: listen to a pre-recorded lecture by Prof. Gandhi. On Wednesdays, we met synchronously to discuss the lecture and readings from the week, led by Prof. Gandhi.
Recorded lecture and virtual seminar.
We had a mix of asynchronous recorded material as well as live sessions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about Mughal Empire and India's history in general especially as it relates to religious and cultural issues.
I learnt about the historical development of the Mughal Empire in India.
General foundation in the history of Mughal India

I gained a lot of new knowledge about Mughal India. The class discussed the history of the empire with incredible tenacity and vigor, and offered a lot of room for critical discussions about peripatetic rulers, the role of religion and the potential for secular governance, as well as counter factual histories. Overall the course offered both a lot of knowledge and fantastic discussions.
How to think about a new era of history
Great class to learn more about South Asian history, interesting readings, covers a lot of different aspects

I was challenged to read a lot more attentively and connect historical knowledge from the first readings of the semester to the final readings of the semester, so as to understand historical themes present within the Mughal empire.

I gained a robust sense of the arc of Mughal court / high politics, and an introduction to various religious movements (such as Millenarianism) of the Mughal era. I learned how to write a ghazal and a masnavi. To a lesser but still significant degree, I learned about the lives of non-nobles during this period.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Greatest strength was the use of perusall app for student engagement and discussion with one another about the readings.
The Wednesday lectures were also always very interesting

Professor Gandhi clearly knows this subject very well, but I felt like discussion was focused more on the interpretation of very specific stories/paintings/pieces of art, and not as much on the readings or even how they related to Mughal India.

This course is cross-listed as both a history and a religious studies course, however, it felt like more of a religious studies course. We focused greatly on the religious aspects of Mughal India and its emperors, but not as much on the historical events of the time. This was slightly disappointing as I had taken it wanting to learn more about the history of the Indian Subcontinent.

Strengths --> great readings, incredible discussions on the Perusall app.
Weakness --> Not enough discussions in class. Felt a little staged because there was a lot of intervention from the instructor at times.
Sometimes the connection between class material and the readings was evident

I really liked this class! Prof. Gandhi was definitely a strength--she is very knowledgeable about the subject, she frequently makes herself available for office hours, and she is generous about deadlines and giving us interesting assignments. I appreciated the opportunity to write an "unessay," or creative research paper, for my final project. I do wish we had received more feedback (aka grades) throughout the term, because while writing this comment in preparation to view my grade, I have no idea what it will be.
Professor Gandhi is so lovely! Readings can be a bit boring sometimes though

The organization of the course and the discussions we had were excellent, but Prof. Gandhi does have a tendency to use South Asian jargon very casually without explaining the words/terms. Because I've grown up with a South Asian background, I could understand most of the terms she used, but I imagine anyone without that background would struggle. She sometimes does the same with South Asian historical facts; she would casually talk about certain Mughal emperors or practices, or Islamic faith/practices, even though many of us (I assume) did not have a formal background in those histories. But otherwise, the course was really, really good. Prof. Gandhi really does care about you as a person, and she does not hesitate to offer any help on projects, meet with you, or restructure the course to best suit your growth. The Perusall tool was really neat and encouraged me to read more attentively and pay attention to the insightful annotations of my classmates. The lectures and readings that Prof. Gandhi picked out were always interesting, and although a bit on the longer side, they were never a drone. It doesn't take long for one to realize what an immense wealth of knowledge Prof. Gandhi has in this subject. This was a really well structured history course and one that many will find to be quite insightful!

This class is very solidgood organization, great teaching, and fun projects / readings.

One suggestion would be that it might be nice to read more of Prof. Ghandi's book, since we were only assigned a few chapters! Dara Shukoh is awesome... :)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Use of perusal succeeded as well as use of the breakout rooms on zoom.

I don't think breakout rooms work. They're awkward, nobody wants to talk, and I don't feel like I learn anything in them. I did appreciate the Perusall assignments though since it's interesting to see how others engage with the same text.
The combination of pre-recorded and live lectures were really helpful! We also used Perusall for annotation assignments, and I thought that was good too.

Use of perusall app was great. It served as a replacement for the discussion post which I personally did not like, since I feel the two different modes offer different means of analysis and should have both been retained. The professor was very understanding on differing student circumstances and incredibly accommodating.
Polls were helpful
Live virtual lecture was good - lots of discussions about the readings and very interactive
I don't have any suggestions to offer; the course was well-structured for me.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Highly recommend this course even if you have no background knowledge about India.

I would do so depending on the students' reasons for taking the course. If they want more knowledge of the religious aspects of the times, then I would recommend this course. But I would be less inclined to do so if the interest was purely historical.
Absolutely! This is a really important class.

Yes. If you are looking for a good course about South Asian history, this is it. It offers room for assessing art history, political history, religious history, and at times even legal history. Really touches upon the breath of history learning and there is a lot of room for critical thinking. The open ended nature of the project also offered incredible space for trying new things.
Yes!
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student! Professor Gandhi is an incredible professor and the material was very interesting and engaging!
If you want to learn more about Mughal India, then yes! But otherwise the work can be a bit boring
Absolutely! Whether you've been raised as a South Asian or you have a keen interest in South Asian history, do take this course!

Yes! A good survey of the Mughal era, and a fun class for anyone who has even a minor interest in Indian history / court politics / religious movements (mainly Hindu and Muslim). We had non-majors and majors alike, and it didn't seem like an issue.
